text:
GEORGE BARBASTATHIS: So
2.71/2.710 is an introductory
optics course.

The idea is that
the students do not

know anything or very little
about optics to begin with.

And so the goal is that
by the end of the course,

they will be able to
not only understand

the very basics of
light propagation,

but also they will be able to
understand the systems that

utilize light for things like
imaging or telecommunications

or a number of different
engineering applications,

and they will also be able to
design systems of their own--

perhaps not very
complicated systems,

but definitely systems that
can do something useful.

So by definition,
then, it means that it

is oriented for students
who are not necessarily

into the physics or electrical
engineering disciplines,

where, normally, you get a
lot of background in optics

even early on,
and the course has

a lot of this orientation of
starting with the very basics
and then building upon them.

So the general pedagogy
is guided by that.

A lot of the basic tools have
to be taught from scratch.

But also I think that helps
because the students actually
pick up a lot of their material.

For example, that
Fourier transforms,

which is a
mathematical technique,

they actually pick it up
in the context of optics,
and that really--

from students and their
advisors' reactions,

I think this is something
that they actually appreciate.

And in terms of
judging performance,

obviously, you have to
take that into account,

that they are actually
building the background there.

But by the end of the
class, they actually

complete a project, at least
the graduate students do,

and they typically
do very, very well.

So my impression is that
from that point of view,

the course succeeds
in its goals.

So I came to MIT
about five years ago,

and before that, a colleague
who is a senior lecturer,

his name is Steve
[? Anton, ?] he

taught the version of
this course three times,

and so this was
really the first time

that our department
offered an optics course,
and it was wildly successful.

He got very good attendance
and very good reviews.

But Steve actually runs
a company outside MIT.
He's not a full-time employee.

So MIT decided this was a good
direction for the department
to go.

So when I came here,
one of my missions

was actually to
create that sequence.

And substantially, why
mechanical engineering

needs that course is because
optics is fundamental in many

of the core
mechanical engineering

disciplines-- for example,
measurement, instrumentation,
controls.

Imaging is a very
important part, very often,

of mechanical engineering
for things such as robotics.

And of course, these are all
interdisciplinary subjects,

but to a very large degree,
they belong to MechE.

Now, in addition to that,
the course, of course,

is open to all MIT
these students.

In fact, I do get students
from electrical engineering

and physics occasionally but
also from other disciplines.

I've had students from
[INAUDIBLE] engineering,

from AeroAstro,
even architecture,
actually, in my class.

And of course, typically,
these are graduate students

for whom some aspect of
optics typical imaging

becomes important
in their research.

And then the course serves them
very well because it gives them

the tools and the
fundamentals to use it,

but it does not require they
have a physics background that

is typically to be expected
in an optics class.

So I have a slightly unusual
schedule in the class.

One of-- there's two
lectures per week.

One of them lasts for
two hours, and the other
lasts for one hour.

So I tried to design
the sequence of topics

so that in the
two-hour session, we

cover a lot of the fundamental
material and a lot of, so

to speak, the heavy stuff,
if I can use the term.

And then in the
one-hour session,

we actually solve problems or
we look into some more detail
into applications, and so on.

So the two-hour
session sometimes

ends up being a little bit
difficult to carry out,

both for me and the students,
because it requires,

you know, it requires
concentrated attention
for a long time.

But I think it pays off because
with a proper structure,

typically, we break once
or twice for a few minutes,

and then I try to
interject jokes,

and so on, during the lecture,
so the students sort of--

they recover their attention
as opposed to falling asleep.

And by the end of
the two-hour lecture,

they have received the material,
which then they see again

in a more practical
form in the one hour,

so I think it
reinforces quite a bit.

So the class has the
typical requirements.

The students have
to do homework,
they have to take exams.

And in addition, the
graduate students,

they have to carry
out the project.

So let me start by saying why
I do not require a project
from the undergraduates.

The reasons are
purely logistical.

I tend to get a lot
of seniors and juniors

from our department,
and both of them,

near the end of the semester
when the project would have

to be carried out, they're
busy by other projects

in other classes,
so it would really
become a huge burden on them.

Graduate students typically
do not have that limitation,
so it is OK.

What I find is that at the
end, when the graduate students

present their projects,
then the graduates,

they typically come into
that session and attend,

so they are
definitely interested.

And occasionally, I had
one or two undergraduates

who got involved in projects,
but it doesn't happen so often.

So what the project is about
is actually very simple.

Typically, I give the students a
few papers from the literature,
typically three or four papers.

What they have to do is
prepare a presentation,

almost a conference-style
presentation-- it is about 15,
20 minutes talk--

as if they were presenting their
own work at the conference.

But of course, it is
not their own work.

It is what they read in
the papers I gave them.

And typically, I
assign them a mentor.

It could be me, it could
be the teaching assistant,

or some of my research students
from my research group.

And then the mentors,
I instruct them

to try to go a little
bit beyond the papers.

Not too far, of course,
because is a class project, not
a research project.

But typically, before
the students present,

they have to do some calculation
or some additional design

based on what they
saw in the papers.

And I think that works
very well because it really

forces them to understand
a little bit deeper

than the traditional
lecture presentation.

And that lasts for
about a month, actually,

and at the end, they
give a presentation.

Of course, this is a
university, so we buy free pizza

for them and all that stuff,
and it's a lot of fun.
Usually, the projects are--

the comments I get
said the projects

are the one thing that they
enjoy a lot about the class.
